title: Understanding the Problem
text: To find the pH of a solution, we need to understand the relationship between the concentration of the solution and the dissociation constant (Ka) of the acid involved.

title: Identify the Reaction
text: NaF is a salt that dissociates into Na+ and F- ions in solution. The F- ion is the conjugate base of HF, a weak acid. The reaction in water is: F- + H2O ⇌ HF + OH-.

title: Use the Kb Expression
text: Since F- is the conjugate base of HF, we can find the base dissociation constant (Kb) using the relation: Kb $$=$$ $$\frac{Kw}{Ka}$$, where Kw is the ion-product constant of water $$1\times{10}^{-14}$$.

title: Calculate Kb
text: Calculate Kb using the formula: Kb $$=$$ $$\frac{Kw}{Ka}$$. Given Kw $$=$$ $$1\times{10}^{-14}$$ and Ka $$=$$ $$6.8\times{10}^{-4}$$.

title: Set Up the ICE Table
text: Set up an ICE (Initial, Change, Equilibrium) table for the reaction F- + H2O ⇌ HF + OH-. Use the initial concentration of F- and the change in concentration to find the equilibrium concentrations.

title: Solve for OH- Concentration
text: Using the Kb expression: Kb $$=$$ $$\frac{[HF][OH-]/[F-][HF][OH-]/[F-]}{[HF][OH-]/[F-]}$$, solve for the concentration of OH- at equilibrium.

title: Calculate pOH
text: Once you have the concentration of OH-, calculate the pOH using the formula: pOH $$=$$ -log[OH-].

title: Find pOH
text: Calculate pOH using the concentration of OH-: pOH $$=$$ $$-\ln\left(1.71\times{10}^{-6}\right)$$.

title: Convert pOH to pH
text: Use the relationship between pH and pOH: pH + pOH $$=$$ $$14$$, to find the pH of the solution.

title: Calculate pH
text: Using the formula pH $$=$$ $$14$$ - pOH, calculate the pH of the solution.
